etymologies: Old English blæc, of Germanic origin

notes.text: Black, designating Americans of African heritage, became the most widely used and accepted term in the 1960s and 1970s, replacing Negro. It is not usually capitalized: black Americans. Through the 1980s, the more formal African American replaced black in much usage, but both are now generally acceptable. Afro-American, first recorded in the 19th century and popular in the 1960s and 1970s, is now heard mostly in anthropological and cultural contexts. Colored people, common in the early part of the 20th century, is now usually regarded as offensive, although the phrase survives in the full name of the NAACP, the National Association for the Advancement of Colored People. An inversion, people of color, has gained some favor, but is also used in reference to other nonwhite ethnic groups: a gathering spot for African Americans and other people of color interested in reading about their cultures. See also colored and person of color

definitions: of the very darkest color owing to the absence of or complete absorption of light; the opposite of white

examples.text: black smoke
her long black hair

definitions: (of the sky or night) completely dark owing to nonvisibility of the sun, moon, or stars

examples.text: the sky was moonless and black

definitions: deeply stained with dirt

examples.text: his clothes were absolutely black

definitions: (of a plant or animal) dark in color as distinguished from a lighter variety

examples.text: Japanese black pine

shortDefinitions: (of plant or animal) dark in colour

definitions: (of coffee or tea) served without milk or cream

examples.text: a mug of black coffee
Doyle took his coffee black

definitions: of or denoting the suits spades and clubs in a deck of cards.
(of a ski run) of the highest level of difficulty, as indicated by black markers positioned along it.
belonging to or denoting any human group having dark-colored skin, especially of African or Australian Aboriginal ancestry

examples.text: he discusses the position of black people in America
the entire cast is black
the Black community

definitions: relating to black people

examples.text: black culture

definitions: (of a period of time or situation) characterized by tragic or disastrous events; causing despair or pessimism

examples.text: five thousand men were killed on the blackest day of the war
the future looks black for those of us interested in freedom

definitions: (of a person's state of mind) full of gloom or misery; very depressed

examples.text: Jean had disappeared and Mary was in a black mood

definitions: (of humor) presenting tragic or harrowing situations in comic terms

examples.text: “Good place to bury the bodies,” she joked with black humor

definitions: full of anger or hatred

examples.text: Roger shot her a black look

definitions: very evil or wicked

examples.text: my soul is steeped in the blackest sin

phrases.text: not as black as one is painted

notes.text: Black, designating Americans of African heritage, became the most widely used and accepted term in the 1960s and 1970s, replacing Negro. It is not usually capitalized: black Americans. Through the 1980s, the more formal African American replaced black in much usage, but both are now generally acceptable. Afro-American, first recorded in the 19th century and popular in the 1960s and 1970s, is now heard mostly in anthropological and cultural contexts. Colored people, common in the early part of the 20th century, is now usually regarded as offensive, although the phrase survives in the full name of the NAACP, the National Association for the Advancement of Colored People. An inversion, people of color, has gained some favor, but is also used in reference to other nonwhite ethnic groups: a gathering spot for African Americans and other people of color interested in reading about their cultures. See also colored and person of color

definitions: black color or pigment

examples.text: a tray decorated in black and green
a series of paintings done only in grays and blacks

definitions: black clothes or material, typically worn as a sign of mourning

examples.text: dressed in the black of widowhood

definitions: darkness, especially of night or an overcast sky

examples.text: the only thing visible in the black was the light of the lantern

definitions: the player of the black pieces in chess or checkers

examples.text: Black's king's defenses are somewhat weakened

shortDefinitions: player of black pieces in chess or draughts

definitions: a black thing, especially a ball or piece in a game.
a member of a dark-skinned people, especially one of African or Australian Aboriginal ancestry.
the situation of not owing money to a bank or of making a profit in a business operation

examples.text: I managed to break even in the first six months—quite a short time for a small business to get into the black
the company just managed to stay in the black

shortDefinitions: situation of not owing money to bank or making profit in business operation

phrases.text: not as black as one is painted

notes.text: Black, designating Americans of African heritage, became the most widely used and accepted term in the 1960s and 1970s, replacing Negro. It is not usually capitalized: black Americans. Through the 1980s, the more formal African American replaced black in much usage, but both are now generally acceptable. Afro-American, first recorded in the 19th century and popular in the 1960s and 1970s, is now heard mostly in anthropological and cultural contexts. Colored people, common in the early part of the 20th century, is now usually regarded as offensive, although the phrase survives in the full name of the NAACP, the National Association for the Advancement of Colored People. An inversion, people of color, has gained some favor, but is also used in reference to other nonwhite ethnic groups: a gathering spot for African Americans and other people of color interested in reading about their cultures. See also colored and person of color

definitions: make (something) black; blacken

examples.text: the house was pocked with bullet holes and blacked by smoke

definitions: make (one's face) black with makeup or another substance, as a disguise or to imitate the appearance of a black person.
refuse to handle (goods), undertake (work), or have dealings with (a person or business) as a way of taking industrial action

examples.text: the union blacked the film because overtime was not being paid

phrases.text: not as black as one is painted
